prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Three Epochs of Band 3: Detection of a Hard State BHXB (TBD)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal aims to provide a > 20 sigma detection of the flux in Band 3 of the next outbursting transient black hole X-ray binary with f_6GHz > 1 mJy. The strong detection is needed to accurately construct a spectral index from the combination of Band 3, 4, 6, and 7 observations. This flux is expected to arise from (continuum) synchrotron emission.
The total request is for this science goal to be perfomred 3 times (i.e., 3 x 3.53 min on source and 3 x 23.25 min total estimated time).
We request that each epoch of these Band 3 detections are taken within 14 days of the previous epoch and that the Band 4, 6, and 7 detections for the same epoch are taken as close together in time as possible.
We note that the combined Bands' observations fit into a single 2 hour scheduling block.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
We ask that the first epoch observation in Band 3 be taken within 48 hours of our triggering of this ToO and that the data for each epoch of Science Goals (Band 3, 4, 6, 7 detections) are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each successive epoch in Band 3 be taken within 10 - 18 days of the previous epoch. However, given that the evolution timescale in black hole X-ray binaries can vary substantially between different sources (days to weeks), we will carefully monitor how rapidly the X-ray emission of our target source evolves. If the source evolves on shorter timescales we ask to work with schedulers to adjust this timescale between successive epochs based on telescope availability.
Our trigger criteria is as follows: A radio detection at 6 GHZ of at least 1 mJy, where the X-ray behaviour (as measured by X-ray satellites, Swift or MAXI) indicates our target black hole X-ray binary outburst is in the hard state.

We ask that the first epoch observation in Band 3 be taken within 48 hours of our triggering of this ToO and that the data for each epoch of Science Goals (Band 3, 4, 6, 7 detections) are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each successive epoch in Band 3 be taken within 10 - 18 days of the previous epoch. However, given that the evolution timescale in black hole X-ray binaries can vary substantially between different sources (days to weeks), we will carefully monitor how rapidly the X-ray emission of our target source evolves. If the source evolves on shorter timescales we ask to work with schedulers to adjust this timescale between successive epochs based on telescope availability.
Our trigger criteria is as follows: A radio detection at 6 GHZ of at least 1 mJy, where the X-ray behaviour (as measured by X-ray satellites, Swift or MAXI) indicates our target black hole X-ray binary outburst is in the hard state.

We ask that the first epoch observation in Band 3 be taken within 48 hours of our triggering of this ToO and that the data for each epoch of Science Goals (Band 3, 4, 6, 7 detections) are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each successive epoch in Band 3 be taken within 10 - 18 days of the previous epoch. However, given that the evolution timescale in black hole X-ray binaries can vary substantially between different sources (days to weeks), we will carefully monitor how rapidly the X-ray emission of our target source evolves. If the source evolves on shorter timescales we ask to work with schedulers to adjust this timescale between successive epochs based on telescope availability.
Our trigger criteria is as follows: A radio detection at 6 GHZ of at least 1 mJy, where the X-ray behaviour (as measured by X-ray satellites, Swift or MAXI) indicates our target black hole X-ray binary outburst is in the hard state.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As we are performing continuum observations, the observing frequencies in Bands 3, 4, 6, and 7 at 97.5, 145, 233, and 343.5 GHz, respectively, are chosen to balance broad spectral coverage while achieving low system temperatures.
As we expect an unresolved source in Band 3, neither uv-coverage nor array configuration are an issue.

Our primary science goals require an accurate measurment of the mm/sub-mm normalization and spectral index of a black hole X-ray binary in outburst. To strongly constrain the SED, we must measure the mm/sub-mm spectral index to a similar precision as the radio spectral index of < 0.05. Extensive simulations indicate that a 20 sigma detection in each of the Bands 3, 4, 6, and 7 will allow us to measure the mm/sub-mm spectral index to a precision of < 0.05, over the entire expected range of radio spectral indices. Given a flat spectrum and a minimum source flux of 1 mJy, a 20 sigma detection leads to a requirement of 0.05 mJy/beam RMS per band.

As we cannot predict when the next transient black hole X-ray binary goes into outburst, these observations must be Target of Opportunity observations.
Transient black hole X-ray binaries display a range of evolution timescales. In our case, the pertinent timescale is the time to evolve from quiescence through the hard accretion state and completely into the soft accretion state. We provide two examples of the extrema of this timescale: ~ 90 days for the 2014-2015 outburst of GX 339-4 and ~ 14 days for the 2009 outburst of H1743-322. We therefore request the most rapid monitoring possible: epoch one taken within about 48 hours of our trigger, and epochs two - three taken two weeks after the previous epochs. If the X-ray evolution is very rapid, we request the ability (on a best-effort basis) to work with schedulers to balance telescope availability and the need for more rapid ALMA observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Three Epochs of Band 7: Detection of a Hard State BHXB (TBD)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal aims to provide a > 20 sigma detection of the flux in Band 7 of the next outbursting transient black hole X-ray binary with f_6GHz > 1 mJy. The strong detection is needed to accurately construct a spectral index from the combination of Band 3, 4, 6, and 7 observations. This flux is expected to arise from (continuum) synchrotron emission.
The total request is for this science goal to be perfomred 3 times (i.e., 3 x 17.64 min on source and 3 x 41.26 min total estimated time).
We request that each epoch of these Band 7 detections are taken within 14 days of the previous epoch and that the Band 3, 4, and 6 detections for the same epoch are taken as close together in time as possible.
We note that the combined Bands' observations fit into a single 2 hour scheduling block.
If poor weather prevents execution (in this band only), the loss of this science goal leads to a 2 times less precise spectral index. As this is preferred over no spectral index, we place this band as our lowest priority.

As we expect an unresolved source in Band 7, neither uv-coverage nor array configuration are an issue.

Our primary science goals require an accurate measurment of the mm/sub-mm normalization and spectral index of a black hole X-ray binary in outburst. To strongly constrain the SED, we must measure the mm/sub-mm spectral index to a similar precision as the radio spectral index of < 0.05. As we cannot predict when the next transient black hole X-ray binary goes into outburst, these observations must be Target of Oppertunity observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Since active galactic nuclei (AGN) likely play a major role in galaxy formation, it is essential that we understand the processes of accretion onto compact objects and accretion-fed outflows,like relativistic jets. Black hole X-ray binaries (BHXBs) provide ideal laboratories for probing jet phenomena as they evolve on timescales of days to months (unlike AGN that evolve over millions of years). Broad-band spectral measurements of this jet emission in BHXBs allow us to constrain the physical conditions in the jet, which can then be coupled to the properties of the accretion flow, probing the mechanism that governs how jets are launched and quenched.
The mm/sub-mm regime bridges a crucial gap between radio and IR frequencies in the jet broad-band jet spectrum. We propose targeting the next outbursting BHXB (f_6GHz> 1mJy) with 3 epochs of ALMA target of opportunity observations to measure the dynamic mm/sub-mm flux in a BHXB. Coupled with our exceptional multi-wavlength coverage, these ALMA observations allow us to accurately measure the mm/sub-mm flux density & spectral index, and constrain the dynamic broad-band spectral energy distribution in BHXBs with unparalleled accuracy.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: In Cycle 2 we submitted a proposal on similar science, Project Code: 2013.1.00751.T, Title: Constraining the Jet properties of Transient X-ray Binaries, PI: Tetarenko
